Greengraph :: Documentation¶

Greengraph is a basic package that will calculate the number of green-enough pixels in a series of satellite images between two locations. This can be used as a coarse approximation of land-usage between the two locations.

The core module code was written by James Hetherington/and others at the Research Software Engineering Course.

class greengraph.Greengraph(start, end)¶

Create a new greengraph object with locations start and end

geolocate(place)¶

Finds the latitude and longitude coordinates of place :param place: Name of a place :return: The coordinates as a tuple

green_between(steps)¶
Parameters:steps – number of locations to sample between
Returns:a list of the number of green pixels (pixels that are more green than blue or red) at the locations given by location_sequence
location_sequence(start, end, steps)¶
Parameters:
  • start – (lat,long) tuple of starting location
  • end – (lat,long) tuple of ending location
  • steps – Number of locations in between to sample
Returns:

A numpy array of (latitude,longitude) locations between start place and end place
class greengraph.Map(lat, long, satellite=True, zoom=10, size=(400, 400), sensor=False)¶

A map object contains the image (png and RGB array) of the location

count_green(threshold=1.1)¶
Parameters:threshold – How much more green (in RGB terms) a pixel needs to have to be called “green”
Returns:the number of green pixels in the map
green(threshold)¶
Parameters:threshold – How much more green (in RGB terms) a pixel needs to have to be called “green”
Returns:A boolean array of whether a pixel is green or not
show_green(threshold=1.1)¶
Parameters:threshold – How much more green (in RGB terms) a pixel needs to have to be called “green”
Returns:an image that highlights the pixels that are green (and black everywhere else)
